awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Low-Cost 2D and 3D Millimeter Wave Image Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to advance a system for millimeter wave (mmWave) imaging and associated data analytics. This system has potential applications such as pharmaceutical manufacturing inspection of items on an individual pill level. The technology could audit the number or type of pills inside a bottle, pouch, or blister pack; bottles inside a case; and it could look for damage, such as a broken vial or bottle. The improved resolution coupled with the proposed data analytics software will provide accurate metrics about an item that does not require costly human labor. In other fields, such as robotics and automation, mmWave sensors enable imaging in inclement weather and smoky environments, where optical sensors fail. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to (1) develop a 3D mmWave imaging system with improved imaging resolution and (2) develop image processing software that can automatically extract image data and rapidly evaluate metrics. This project will focus on development of 60+ GHz 3D imaging solutions and analytics to retrieve important metrics from those images. By increasing the frequency of operation to 60+ GHz, mmWave image resolution can be improved to 3 – 5 mm voxel size. Additionally, while mmWave images can be produced in near-real-time, these images must still be analyzed by a human. The analytics software to be developed in Phase II will automatically extract key metrics about the scene specific to each industry use case. This project will advance the state of the art in mmWave imaging by developing a low-cost, modular, high-resolution mmWave imaging system that is coupled with automated analytics, enabling a low-cost automated auditing function with broad industry applicability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Across a wide variety of industries, ranging from packaged goods manufacturing, to e-commerce fulfillment, the retail supply chain, and pharma manufacturing and distribution, there is a tremendous drive toward automated material handling systems to reduce labor cost and improve accuracy in packaging and handling items. ThruWave offers a unique, patented 3D imaging solution that leverages human-safe millimeter waves (mmWaves) to overcome the occlusion problems that plague existing computer vision systems that use ordinary optical cameras. ThruWave's mmWave image sensors have the unique ability to image individual items inside sealed packages,   because mmWaves penetrate most common packaging materials such as paper, plastic, corrugated cardboard, air packs, and wood. ThruWave's solution includes proprietary 3D mmWave image sensors, along with automated image interpretation software that extracts key analytics including process variables such as item count, fill fraction, and the presence of damage or contaminants - all without opening sealed packages. Our solution gives customers the ability to audit 100% of cartons in high-throughput environments in real-time.   

ThruWave was awarded a SBIR Phase I grant in 2018. We used this grant to support research and development for our mmWave sensing prototype and image reconstruction algorithm. The research done during this project led directly to the development of our current 24 GHz mmWave sensing platform and the image reconstruction algorithm used in production systems.  

We were awarded a Phase II grant in 2020. The technical objectives of this project were research and development supporting implementation of a higher frequency (60 GHz) mmWave sensing platform and development of data analytics software that is able to automatically interpret mmWave images for important metadata and process variables.  

We were awarded a TECP supplement in April 2022 to support research and development that fulfilled a technical requirement with a commercial partner and in November 2021, we installed a pilot imaging system in one of their facilities. Our TECP funded efforts resulted in a new software module to detect problems that arose during the initial use case. 

We were awarded a Phase IIB supplement award in 2023 to pursue additional R&D that further accelerated the commercialization of the Phase II project. The technical goals of Phase IIB followed on technical progress made in the SBIR Phase I and Phase II programs and focused on additional analytics models to meet customer needs using advanced and novel methods as well as software infrastructure work to increase the robustness of our architecture.  

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2023
Modified by: Claire M Watts
